column1: PhD in Molecular Biology/ Genome Engineering (d/f/m) DM.271.22b;UnternehmensbeschreibungAn ERC-funded PhD position is available in the team of Stefan Mundlos at the Max Planck Institute for Molecular Genetics / Charité Universitätsmedizin Berlin
column2: Germany.StellenbeschreibungThe project is focused on the application and development of technologies for genome engineering in mouse stem cells. This includes the design and production of synthetic DNA based on technologies to synthesize the yeast genome (Sc2.0) and site-directed insertion of BAC-size DNA in the mouse genome. This strategy allows for the generation and replacement of large DNA fragments in the mouse genome. Using this technology
column3: we aim at deciphering the regulatory logic of gene expression in complex genomes. This includes the dissection and manipulation of 3D genome structure

column5: as well as the function of non-coding RNAs.The project is in cooperation with the Max Planck Institute for Molecular Genetics https://www.molgen.mpg.de/2168/en - one of the leading institutions for genomics research in Germany with approx. 350 employees.The ideal candidate should hold a Master in Biology or similar ideally with a background in genetics

column1: The Division of Pediatric Neurooncology at the German Cancer Research Center and the Hopp Children's Cancer Center Heidelberg is seeking for the International Pediatric Cancer Data Mining project three
Postdoctoral Scientists in Computational Biology (Ref-No. 2023-0080)
Job description:
The Division of Pediatric Neurooncology offers a total of three postdoctoral positions for two different research groups.
1. Genomic data mining of clinical bulk sequencing

This group led by Dr. Robert J. Autry focuses on developing computational methods and workflows to answer clinically relevant questions across the range of childhood cancers by interrogating genomic and epi-genomic alterations. We aim to elucidate the mechanisms underlying cancer predisposition
column2: tumorigenesis and therapeutic response to discover novel therapeutic targets and to improve diagnosis
column3: prevention and clinical outcome in children.

column1: Two postdocs will perform analyses on large-scale bulk genomic sequencing data sets (Whole genome/exome
column2: RNA
column3: methylation
column4: other genomic and epigenomic data types). One position is working on cancer predisposition projects (rare variant burden testing
column5: somatic second hit analysis and collaborations with other institutes). The other postdoc will work on high-grade glioma data to identify potential targets and vulnerabilities in this very high-risk cancer type. Both postdocs will independently manage their own academic research projects
column6: coordinate to meet project deadlines under the mentorship and support of their supervisor. They will also prepare publications
column7: present data both internally and externally
column9: and advise and inform other group members on relevant methodology and analytical approaches.

column1: 2. Single-cell / spatial genomics data mining

This group led by Dr. Supat Thongjuea aims to understand cellular heterogeneity and molecular mechanisms in childhood cancer. The group focuses on developing and applying computational approaches to analyze single-cell multi-omics and spatial information to uncover patterns and extract relevant knowledge underlying disease mechanisms.
One postdoc will work on data mining and integration of single-cell muti-omics / spatial datasets (RNA-seq
column2: Spatial
column3: ATAC-seq
column4: copy-number and mutational analysis
column5: all at single-cell resolution) including data from longitudinal samples from the same patients generated within the Division of Pediatric Neurooncology. The postdoc will apply existing or develop new computational
column7: and machine learning techniques to uncover molecular patterns for understanding disease mechanisms (e.g.
column8: therapy resistance in cancer). The postdoc will independently manage own academic research
column9: coordinate work to meet project deadlines while receiving mentorship and support from their supervisor. He/she will also prepare research publications and internal/external presentations
column11: and act as a source of information and advice to other group members on methodology and analytical approaches.

column1: Background / Objectives

The Multitrophic Plant-Microbe Interactions group aims at understanding the fundamental mechanisms that underlie the structure and the functions of multi-kingdom microbial consortia colonizing plant roots (see group website). The ERC-funded project MICROBIOSIS will focus on the fascinating
column2: yet overlooked circuits that connect root microbiota composition belowground with aboveground leaf development (see project). The objective is to identify conserved strategies used by distantly related plant species for long-distance communication with root microbes and to design synthetic microbial communities that promote resistance to multiple aboveground stresses. The project will involve the use of tractable microbial communities
column3: cutting-edge metabolome
column4: microbiome and grafting techniques
column5: as well as genetic engineering methods and advanced gnotobiotic plant growth systems to mechanistically understand and engineer these circuits.

column1: PhD Student Biology - R-loop
column2: RNA Biology (m/f/d);"Are you interested in RNA biology and are looking for a PhD position? Join our newly established research training group (RTG) with a focus on R-loop biology: “4R - R-loop regulation in robustness and resilience”.

column1: Life Science in Mainz has a strong focus on RNA biology
column2: ranging from molecular mechanisms to diagnostics and therapeutics. Many research groups in our scientific community have come across so-called R-loops as important regulatory intermediates in the context of their research. Although it has long been appreciated that RNA can base-pair and hybridize to complementary DNA
column3: it has only recently been appreciated that such RNA-DNA hybrids can have regulatory roles within the genome. When RNA-DNA hybrids lead to the displacement of one strand of DNA
column4: and hence a three stranded structure
column5: it is referred to as an “R-loop”. Indeed
column6: RNA-DNA hybrids and R-loops have recently been demonstrated to influence processes such as transcription
column7: DNA repair and telomere maintenance
column8: which may indicate that R-loops play important roles during ageing. However
column9: when R-loops are not efficiently managed
column10: they can lead to genome instability and disease. Within the “4R RTG”
column11: we will investigate how R-loops regulate biological processes across scales
column12: from molecules to organisms. At the same time the mechanistic regulation of R-loops themselves will be interrogated.

column1: Pending funding
column2: we are currently offering 12 PhD positions
column3: starting on October 1
column5: to work on various aspects of R-loop biology. Are you an ambitious
column6: young scientist enthusiastic about RNA Biology and looking forward to interacting with colleagues from multiple disciplines and cultures? Then joining our “4R RTG” is your opportunity to give your scientific career a flying start! All you need is:

column1: • Master or equivalent
• Interactive personality & good command of English
• 2 letters of reference
• Exciting
column2: interdisciplinary projects in a vividly international environment
column3: with English as our working language

column1: • Membership within the International PhD Programme (IPP) on Gene Regulation
column2: Epigenetics & Genome Stability
column3: a lively community of more than 190 PhD students from 44 different countries

column1: • Advanced training in scientific techniques and professional skills

column1: Professorship “Molecular Organismal Biology- (f/m/d);"The Faculty of Biosciences at Heidelberg University invites applications for the
Professorship “Molecular Organismal Biology” (f/m/d)
Open rank: tenure track W1 or tenured W3
at the Centre for Organismal Studies (COS) to be occupied at the next possible date.
The successful candidate (f/m/d) shall support and expand research activities of COS by addressing fundamental questions in molecular organismal biology
column2: in particular
column3: related to developmental physiology in genetically tractable animal models such as zebrafish
column4: medaka or fly. The successful candidate will develop an innovative research program that promotes collaboration with colleagues at COS and the Heidelberg life science community. The successful candidate will integrate into existing research consortia and/or participate in initiatives to create new collaborative networks (excellence clusters
column5: CRCs). The professorship will contribute to teaching in the biosciences within the study programmes Bachelor “Biowissenschaften”
column6: Bachelor ”Biologie 50%” (Lehramt) and Master of Molecular Biosciences.

column1: COS is a vibrant research center dedicated to elucidating the development
column2: physiology and evolution of plants and animals using molecular biology
column3: cell biology and genetics. COS comprises 24 independent research groups and offers excellent conditions for research and teaching in an international environment. Our work is supported by the CellNetworks Core Technology Platform (Deep Sequencing
column4: Nikon Imaging Center
column5: electron microscopy and Metabolomics). A detailed description of the research and teaching activities of COS is available on the COS webpage https://www.cos.uni-heidelberg.de/en.

column1: The professorship is open to candidates on both entry levels (tenure track W1 or tenured W3). A tenure track professorship (W1) will initially be limited to six years and
column2: following a positive tenure evaluation
column3: will be converted to a permanent W3 full professorship. The evaluation statute is available on https://www.uni-heidelberg.de/university/staff/career/tenure-track/index.html.

column1: In accordance with Article 51 (Higher Education Act of the state Baden-Württemberg)
column2: the appointment to a tenure track professorship requires a completed degree
column3: an excellent doctorate and pedagogical aptitude
column4: which has generally been proven through teaching experience. If you spent time employed as a research assistant (before or after your doctorate)
column5: this employment and the period of your doctoral studies combined should not exceed six years. The appointment to a full professorship additionally requires either a Habilitation
column7: or equivalent qualifications (Article 47

column1: Please submit your application including the application form
column2: CV
column3: publication and third-party funding lists
column4: teaching experience
column5: previous research activities
column6: future research projects and references with contact details in a single PDF to the dean of the Faculty of Biosciences at Heidelberg University
column7: Prof. Dr. Rüdiger Hell

column1: Heidelberg University stands for equal opportunities and diversity. Qualified female candidates are especially invited to apply. Postdoctoral Fellow;"About the team/job
EMBL Hamburg
column2: as part of the IMAGINE Consortium have been awarded a grant by the European Commission: IMAGINE: Next Generation Imaging Technologies to probe structure and function of biological specimen across scales in their natural context. As part of this funding is a postdoctoral position to work on Work Package 1 of the Imagine Consortium. Work Package 1 targets hard X-ray imaging of biological samples exploring the potential of imaging biological matter in its near native state aiming to develop sample handling techniques and instrumentation to enable routine experiments at both room and cryogenic temperatures and at different X-ray facilities.

column1: Your role
A key focus of this position is the development of the High Throughput Tomography (HiTT) pipeline. This includes the development of sample handling processes
column2: advanced instrumentation and data collection techniques for imaging biological samples. The goal is to produce a streamlined hard X-ray imaging technique pipeline to take a user from an unprepared sample though to a 3D reconstruction of the X-ray data collected on that sample. The development of common sample mounts and/or the ability to transfer samples easily between different facilities will be essential to the collaboration and ensuring compatibility between modalities need also to be explored. Vital to the success of the project is the collaborative spirit between imaging facilities and imaging modalities. All developments will be carried out in such a way that their implementation elsewhere is both possible and expected.

column1: You have
For this role you have:
• A PhD in an area broadly relevant to tissue imaging in biology and/or X-ray instrumentation development.
• An aptitude for both methods and instrumentation development at the physics: biology interface.
• An affinity for collaborative multidisciplinary work.
• A good command of spoken and written English as the working language at EMBL is English.
You might also have
You might also have specific expertise in one or more of the following areas:
• Detailed knowledge and understanding of biological X-ray imaging particularly in relation to its application to soft biological tissue.
• Synchrotron experience and/or experience of X-ray imaging techniques.
• Tissue sample handling and preparation techniques including in one or more of the following areas: X-ray imaging
column2: electron microscopy
column3: light microscopy.

column1: • Computer programming and software development for data analysis (preferably Python and/or C++.
• Experience in 3D Image segmentation.
• Experience using UNIX/Linux command line interfaces and/or cluster based computing resources.
• Experience in using CAD Software.
Why join us
EMBL is curiosity-driven
column2: community-oriented and international. As an inclusive
column3: equal opportunity employer
column4: EMBL offers attractive conditions and benefits appropriate to an international research organisation with a very collegial and family friendly working environment. Competitive salary
column5: a relaxed culture
column6: ongoing professional development and library all make EMBL a great place to work. Our mission has us exploring life at all levels
column7: and creating new ways to look at the world. Our reputation is built on scientific excellence and collaboration
column8: and the projects we take on require all kinds of people and working styles
column9: from big-picture creatives to patient detail-seekers.

column1: What else you need to know
We are Europe’s flagship research laboratory for the life sciences – an intergovernmental organisation performing scientific research in disciplines including molecular biology
column2: physics
column3: chemistry and computer science. We are an international
column4: innovative and interdisciplinary laboratory with approx. 1900 employees from many nations
column5: operating across six sites
